summary: Interactive romantic Valentine proposal web page (HTML/CSS/JS) with Yes/No buttons, evasive No behavior, and meme popups; designed to run on iPad Chrome.
architectural_notes: Replace single angry-cat meme popup with a 3-step sequence of meme assets shown on successive 3rd-No events (polite -> firmer -> aggressive), cycling or stopping at final stage as designed.
Add a subtle highlight/glow/underline animation around the name "Navera" within the main question text without changing the overall layout.
imageRequirements:
## Required Images
- Romantic and caring meme-style square image (good-choice-romantic-meme-v3.dim_900x900.png)

existing_features.title: Create a single-screen romantic Valentine proposal UI that asks the user: "Will you be my Valentine?" and presents exactly two large buttons: "Yes" and "No", using a pink-and-white romantic theme.

Implement evasive behavior for the "No" button so that on hover (mouse) or touch/pointer interaction (mobile/tablet), it moves to a new position within the visible viewport/container, making it difficult to click.
Track "No" interactions and, on every third successful "No" click/tap, display an overlay/modal showing an angry cat meme image; the overlay must be dismissible to continue interacting with the page.
On "Yes" click/tap, display an overlay/modal with a meme image that includes the text: "Good choice" (English).

Add simple, delightful interactions/animation polish appropriate for a romantic page (e.g., subtle button animations, soft transitions), without adding additional app features beyond the Valentine prompt and the required meme popups.

Store the required meme images as static frontend assets and reference them directly from the frontend (do not fetch via backend). Place generated images under frontend/public/assets/generated and use them in the modals.

Change the existing "No"-click modal behavior so that on every 3rd successful "No" click/tap (i.e., counts 3, 6, 9, ...), the app shows a meme popup that rotates through three different memes in a repeating cycle, escalating in tone from polite (first) to more annoyed (second) to aggressive (third).

Update the UI for the rotating "No"-click meme modal so that it uses English user-facing text and reflects the escalation level (polite/annoyed/aggressive) in the modal title and/or dismiss button text, without adding any new app features beyond the existing Valentine prompt and meme popups.

Add two new static meme images for the "No"-click rotation (polite and annoyed), store them under frontend/public/assets/generated, and update the frontend to reference all three "No"-click meme images as static assets (no backend fetch). The existing angry cat meme should be used as the aggressive third meme in the rotation.

Add a new set of static meme image assets under frontend/public/assets/generated, and update the frontend to use the new images for: (1) the "Yes" (Good choice) modal image and (2) the three rotating "No"-click escalation modal images (polite, annoyed, aggressive).
Ensure the updated meme images render correctly on iPad Chrome (no stretching or broken paths) and preserve the existing layout responsiveness and rounded/shadow styling in the modals.

Update the main question headline in frontend/src/App.tsx to include the name "Navera" and add a clear, romantic highlight effect around the word "Navera" (e.g., soft glow + subtle underline/marker effect) while preserving the existing responsive layout and overall Valentine styling.

Replace the image used in the "Yes" (Good Choice) modal with a new static image that feels romantic and caring, and update frontend/src/App.tsx to reference the new asset under /assets/generated/ while keeping the existing modal sizing (object-contain), rounded corners, and shadow styling.
